content: The Act may be cited as the "VA Expiring Authorities Extension Act of 2013" and includes a table of contents. The "VA Expiring Authorities Extension Act of 2013" includes provisions for extending various programs and authorities related to disabled veterans, adaptive sports assistance, transportation to VA facilities, nursing home care, mental health services for veterans, housing assistance for homeless veterans, and advisory committees. The "VA Expiring Authorities Extension Act of 2013" extends housing assistance for homeless veterans, advisory committees, education commission authority, vendee loans requirements, and medical disabilities examinations by contract physicians under Title 38, United States Code. Budgetary effects will be determined by the latest statement for compliance with the Statutory Pay-As-You-Go Act of 2010. Budgetary effects will be determined by the latest statement for compliance with the Statutory Pay-As-You-Go Act of 2010. Extension of authorization of appropriations for payment of a monthly assistance allowance to disabled veterans training or competing in large-scale adaptive sports programs is also addressed. The "VA Expiring Authorities Extension Act of 2013" extends housing assistance for homeless veterans, advisory committees, education commission authority, vendee loans requirements, and medical disabilities examinations under Title 38, United States Code. Extension of authorization of appropriations for payment of a monthly assistance allowance to disabled veterans training or competing in large-scale adaptive sports programs is also addressed. Additionally, the Act reauthorizes and modifies the Adaptive Sports Assistance Program to provide adaptive sports opportunities for disabled veterans in Commonwealths and Territories of the United States. The Secretary may make grants to eligible entities for adaptive sports programs for disabled veterans and Armed Forces members. Eligible entities must have experience in managing large-scale adaptive sports programs. Additional application requirements include detailing partnerships, grant fund usage, and anticipated costs. The entity must detail partnerships, anticipated costs, financial controls, performance metrics, and use of grant funds for administrative expenses when applying for grants for adaptive sports programs for disabled veterans and Armed Forces members. The entity receiving a grant for adaptive sports programs can use a portion for administrative and personnel expenses, with limits on the percentage based on the fiscal year. Personnel expenses do not include reimbursement for coaching or training. Funding for these programs is specified in subsection (g) of the section. The funding for adaptive sports programs is amended to remain available without fiscal year limitation. Assistance under this section is limited to fiscal years 2010 through 2016. A report on grant usage must be submitted to Congress within 18 months of the enactment of this Act. The report on grants awarded under section 521A of title 38, United States Code, as amended by this Act, must assess the provision of adaptive sports opportunities to veterans and members of the Armed Forces, oversight of fund usage, and benefits provided through programs developed with grants. Technical amendments include changing references to the United States Olympic Committee to eligible entities. The section is amended to change references to the United States Olympic Committee to eligible entities in subsections (b), (c), and (d) of title 38, United States Code. The section is amended to change references to the United States Olympic Committee to eligible entities in subsections of title 38, United States Code. The eligible entity that receives a grant under this section will now be referenced in various paragraphs, replacing mentions of the United States Olympic Committee. The adapted sports opportunities funded by the grant will also be specified in place of the integrated adaptive sports program. Adaptive sports programs for disabled veterans and members of the Armed Forces are addressed in section 512A. The Secretary of Veterans Affairs may implement regulations through interim final rules to ensure grants for adaptive sports for disabled veterans and members of the Armed Forces are awarded before the end of fiscal year 2014. Additionally, authorities for transporting individuals to VA facilities, operating the VA regional office in Manila, and providing nursing home care to certain veterans with service-connected disabilities are extended until December 31, 2014. The extension of various services for veterans, including nursing home care, treatment for mentally ill and homeless veterans, housing assistance, and advisory committees, has been extended until December 31, 2014. The extension of various services for veterans, including advisory committees and medical disabilities examinations, has been extended until December 31, 2014.
